text2: decked with cannons and blasters. Talking heads in the media stoked fears; endless conspirasists on social networks

text: An international call rang for volunteer soldiers to participate in a training program dedicated to the exploration of the alien craft on the Moon. As a Petty Officer in the US Navy, I hungered for real action and thrills. I signed up without a second’s thought, going against the wishes of my family and friends. How could I ignore an opportunity to become an astronaut solider?

The training was more brutal than I had anticipated—I lost my stomach hundreds of times and slept very little. I couldn’t count the times I wanted to give up and go home, but my dreams kept pushing for space and the Moon. Three months later, I was selected along with 1000 other international astronaut soldiers for OPERATION ALIEN BATTLECRAFT. The night before the launch, I stayed up at the window, waiting for dawn, my eyes stuck on the Moon and its new neighbor.

The day of the launch had arrived. I and three other soldiers boarded combat ship X2Y-325 with a course set for the southeastern location of the alien craft. Our ascent went as smoothly as expected—even if I was overcome with nausea. But the sight of the Earth and the glory of the stars dissipated whatever stomach troubles I had. Once we approached the Moon, the rear of our ship exploded! We braced ourselves for a crash landing.

Our team leader, Captain Nora Cross, suffered a blow to the head, killing her instantly. We radioed headquarters, updating them on our situation. Our orders were curt and simple: proceed to the alien battlecraft and join the team from combat ship X2Y-326. We received their location on our maps. It was time to enter the eye on the Moon.
